summary: Roundup of area news.

headline: What India and China Google
summary: Indian and Chinese web surfers look for very different things on Google, judging by a search term analysis released by the firm this week. Some snapshots.

headline: Bob Feller Dies at 92
summary: Hall of Famer Bob Feller, the winningest pitcher in Cleveland Indians history and one of baseball's greatest right-handers, died on Wednesday night of acute leukemia.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: China's Prime Minister in India, a protest in New Delhi, Buddhist monks in Sikkim and more.

headline: 2010 Car Launches in India
summary: India's thriving car market lured companies to unveil their new commercial vehicles here, at a time when Indian auto makers posted record monthly sales. Some snapshots.

headline: Asia Mostly Lower on Spain Worries
summary: Most Asian stock markets ended lower Wednesday, with Hong Kong shares suffering afternoon losses as a move to put Spain's sovereign ratings on review for possible downgrade hurt sentiment. Hong Kong finished down 2%.

headline: Asylum Seekers Killed in Boat Crash
summary: As many as 50 Iranian and Iraqi asylum seekers were killed and dozens wounded after a boat they were traveling on was dashed against rocks in heavy seas off the coast of Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean, authorities said.

headline: Dow Loses Grip on Gains
summary: Stocks fell slightly despite improving U.S. economic data as investors continued to worry about euro-zone finances.

headline: Harrisburg in Pa. Distressed-Cities Program
summary: Pennsylvania accepted Harrisburg into its oversight program for distressed cities on Wednesday as the capital city struggles with fiscal problems.

headline: Russia's ARMZ Buys Mantra for $1.15 Billion
summary: Russia's ARMZ Uranium Holding agreed to acquire Australia's Mantra Resources Ltd. for about $1.15 billion in its bid to acquire low-cost sources of uranium for its parent, Russia's largest utility.

headline: Elan, Eisai to Pay $214 Million to U.S.
summary: The U.S. arms of drug companies Elan Corp. and Eisai Co. will pay $214 million to resolve allegations that they illegally promoted the epilepsy drug Zonegran.

headline: Christmas Day Terror Suspect Faces Expanded Indictment
summary: A grand jury in Detroit returned an expanded indictment Wednesday against the Nigerian man accused of attempting to bomb a Northwest flight bound for Detroit on Christmas Day last year.

headline: Madoff Figure Struggles to Make Bail
summary: A longtime back-office employee of convicted Ponzi schemer Bernard Madoff has been unable to meet some of the conditions related to her $5 million bail and could be remanded to jail as soon as Thursday afternoon.

headline: Cuomo Settles With Two Firms in Pension Probe
summary: HFV Management co-founder Barrett Wissman has agreed to pay $12 million to the state, while Odyssey Investment Partners will pay $400,000.

headline: Acquitted Immigrant Faces Deportation
summary: An immigrant acquitted of plotting a terror attack in Chicago faces a renewed threat of deportation after the U.S. lifted its post-earthquake ban on repatriating people to Haiti.

headline: Vietnam Battles Dark Side of Boom
summary: Up-and-coming Vietnam is grappling with the downward spiral of its currency, the dong. Moody's signaled the extent of the problems, downgrading its rating on Vietnamese government debt.

headline: Traders Pick Up Insurance on Regions Financial
summary: Options traders used a brief jump in Regions Financial's stock to snap up some portfolio protection.

headline: Euro Sinks on Spain Debt Worries
summary: Euro tumbled after Moody's Investors Service put Spain's credit rating on review for a potential downgrade. Positive U.S. data helped the dollar to rise.

headline: Lake Views in Idaho
summary: Gut renovated in 2004, this 8,300-square-foot home boasts views of Lake Coeur d'Alene from every room and comes with its own boat slip.

headline: Small Caps Give Large Returns
summary: The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks has been a solid outperformer during the most recent period of stock-market optimism, despite being seen as riskier, more volatile investments.

headline: 'Fashion File' Book Excerpt
summary: Read an excerpt from 'The Fashion File: Advice, Tips and Inspiration From the Costume Designer of Mad Men' by Janie Bryant.

headline: Texas Style
summary: This home in the Texas Hill Country style in Austin features five bedrooms, an 18-foot box beam ceiling, a pool and stand alone pool house.

headline: U.S. Says GM Buys Back Preferred Shares
summary: The U.S. Treasury said Wednesday that General Motors had completed the repurchase of preferred stock issued to the government as part of the car maker's U.S. bailout last year.

headline: Christoph Wilcke: Waiting for Reform in Riyadh
summary: Is one man's will strong enough to deliver change in Saudi Arabia?

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, a woman carts scrap metal in Spain, Abu Dhabi is home to an $11 million Christmas tree, the Eiffel Tower gets a touch-up and more.

headline: Selloff in Treasurys Continues
summary: The flailing Treasury market showed no sign of relief as selling continued to mount from a broad range of market participants.

headline: IPO Market Turns Murky
summary: Three of the four deals priced below their expected ranges and struggled on their first day of trading.

headline: China's iSoftStone Jumps on Debut
summary: Chinese technology-services company iSoftStone Holdings kicked off the final week of IPO issuance in the U.S. with trading gains, rising 28% on its first day of trading.

headline: Southwest to Add Larger Planes
summary: Southwest Airlines plans to acquire at least 70 larger Boeing 737 aircraft over the next three years for expansion in congested domestic markets and the carrier's first international services.

headline: Betting on 'Entrepreneurial' Stocks
summary: A Babson professor creates a mutual fund of public companies based on their entrepreneurial, small-business characteristics.

headline: Thitinan Pongsudhirak: Thailand's Misrule by Law
summary: The judicial and military establishment are skewing the playing field in favor of the ruling party.

headline: Oil Prices Climb as Stockpiles Fall
summary: Crude futures settled higher, rebounding from early losses after U.S. oil stockpiles posted their biggest weekly decline in eight years.

headline: U.K. FSA Set to Release RBS Report
summary: The U.K. Financial Services Authority is set to release a report on its 18-month government investigation into RBS and the events that led to its near collapse, following a political outcry over the report's secrecy.

headline: Violence Erupts in Greek Strike
summary: Greek police fought running street battles with hundreds of anarchist youths Wednesday as tens of thousands of workers marched through central Athens to protest against government austerity measures and labor-market changes.

headline: Violence Erupts in Greek Strike
summary: Greek police fought running street battles with hundreds of anarchist youths as tens of thousands of workers marched through central Athens to protest against government austerity measures.

headline: Gold Settles Modestly Lower
summary: Investors shed safe-harbor purchases of gold as upbeat economic data and slower-than-expected inflation stoked risk appetite.

headline: Drug Regulator Urges Innovation
summary: The low level of successful drug innovation from the pharmaceuticals industry represents a major public health concern and an enormous waste of money, Europe's outgoing top drug regulator said.

headline: Siemens Tie-Up Augurs Well for Atos
summary: Atos Origin's acquisition of Siemens Information Services may look like a bad idea at first glance. In fact, the omens are good.

headline: Unease Over Spain Pressures Europe, Asia Stocks
summary: World stock markets closed mostly lower after Moody's Investors Service put Spain's government bond ratings on review for possible downgrade. Spain's IBEX index fell 1.5%.

headline: U.K. Retail Sales Soar
summary: U.K. retail sales were stronger than expected in December as consumers rushed to buy goods before a January sales-tax increase.

headline: Atos's Shares Surge on Deal
summary: Shares in French IT services group Atos Origin surged after it said it will buy Siemens's IT Solutions and Services business for $1.14 billion.

headline: U.S.: Rare-Earth Supplies Face Possible Disruptions
summary: Supplies of rare-earth materials, mined mostly in China and used in a handful of clean-energy products, could be cut off or disrupted in future years, according to the U.S. Energy Department.

headline: Task Force: Government Should Pay to Modernize Air-Traffic System
summary: A federal task force called on the government Wednesday to bear much of the cost for modernizing the nation's delay-prone air-traffic control system.

headline: Chevron Expands in Kazakhstan
summary: A Chevron-led group agreed to spend $5.4 billion to more than double capacity at a Kazakhstan pipeline.

headline: Canadian Highway Partially Reopens
summary: Canada has partially opened a stretch of highway in southwestern Ontario after rescuing 237 motorists stranded by a blizzard, but auto plants in the area are still crippled by a parts shortage.

headline: Lehman Ends Part of Derivatives Suit
summary: A U.S. bankruptcy judge approved a settlement between Lehman Brothers and two parties, including Bank of New York Mellon, over derivatives deals that had divided courts on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Joy Global Profit Climbs
summary: Joy Global's fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 18%, as the company benefited from strong margins on its underground mining machinery.

headline: Madrid Leads European Market Losses
summary: Spain's IBEX 35 fell after Moody's warned that it might downgrade the government's credit rating. Financial stocks tumbled.

headline: Chrysler, VW Set Recalls
summary: Chrysler Group and Volkswagen announced recalls of 367,350 minivans and 228,236 cars, respectively, the latest setbacks for auto makers amid a generally improving climate for the industry.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Virgin Atlantic Receives Approaches
summary: Virgin Atlantic has received a "number of lines of enquiry" about tie-ups with rivals, the U.K. airline said.

headline: U.K. Unemployment Rises
summary: U.K. unemployment in the three months to October rose for the first time in six months, raising fears of a jobless recovery as the country heads into a prolonged period of austerity.

headline: Bank Levy Looms in South Korea
summary: South Korea, preparing long-threatened capital controls, will announce a bank levy as early as Sunday.

headline: Kodak, Shutterfly Trade Patent Suits
summary: Kodak and rival Shutterfly have filed suit against each other, claiming patent infringement as competition heats up in the online photography market.

headline: Otsuka Rises 1.9% in Tokyo Debut
summary: Otsuka Holdings capped a long-awaited IPO with a 1.9% rise in its Tokyo debut, easing fears of another post-listing breakdown that could tarnish an otherwise fairly robust year for offerings in Japan.

headline: Sentiment Sours Among Japanese Manufacturers
summary: Sentiment among Japan's big manufacturers took a turn for the worse, but not by as much as expected, the BOJ's tankan survey showed, suggesting the central bank may hold off on any new efforts to stimulate the economy.

headline: Merkel: Crisis Mechanism Will Bring Security
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said European leaders will approve a permanent facility to rescue financially-stressed governments on Thursday.

headline: Complicated Conversion
summary: After converting at least five apartments in Manhattan, the owners of this combined West 67th Street condo in Lincoln Square met their match.

headline: Agrium to Sell Assets to Cargill
summary: Agrium reached a deal to sell a majority of AWB's commodity-management businesses to Cargill.

headline: Indianapolis Contemporary
summary: This four-bedroom home has 84 windows with forest views, a custom-built minimalist kitchen and a living room that features two catwalks.

headline: China Again Big Buyer of Treasurys
summary: China boosted its holdings of U.S. Treasurys to its largest position in nearly a year during October as it remained the largest foreign holder of U.S. government debt, the Treasury Department said.

headline: Japanese Yields End Mixed
summary: Japanese government bond yields ended narrowly mixed Wednesday, with little impact from a Bank of Japan quarterly survey that showed a deterioration in business sentiment.

headline: Anil Ambani Firms Strike Deals Worth $3 Billion With Chinese Banks
summary: Two Indian companies controlled by billionaire Anil Ambani received about $3.04 billion of financing commitments from a consortium led by Chinese banks, helping one of them ease immediate debt pressures and the other to secure funds for a power project.

headline: Ratings Firms Add to Pressure on Euro Leaders
summary: A decision to put Belgium, in addition to Spain, on watch for a possible downgrade may signal that ratings firms are taking a more critical approach to heavily indebted core euro-zone members.

headline: EU Agrees on Budget Increase
summary: European institutions agreed on increasing next year's budget for the European Union by 2.91% next year after months of wrangling.

headline: Polish Mobile Battle Ends
summary: Deutsche Telekom and Vivendi settled a years-long legal battle over Polish mobile-phone operator PTC, giving the German company sole ownership.

headline: MOIL Shares Rise 47% on Debut
summary: Shares of state-owned manganese miner MOIL made a strong debut on Indian bourses, aided by the robust prospects for manganese demand in the country.

headline: Kumba Iron Ore Chairman Quits
summary: Kumba Iron Ore, a South African mining company disputing rights given to another company at its main operation, said Chairman Lazarus Zim has resigned because of an impending conflict of interest.

headline: Inditex Net Profit Jumps 42%
summary: The Spanish fashion retailer Inditex reported a 42% increase in nine-month net profit, boosted by higher sales despite the difficult economic environment, and outlined plans to speed up its expansion.

headline: Hoenig Casts Final Dissent
summary: The Federal Reserve's meeting Tuesday marked the final opportunity for Kansas City Fed President Thomas Hoenig, who will retire next year, to express his disapproval of the central bank's policies.

headline: Hyundai Group Financing in Doubt
summary: Hyundai Group's bid to buy a controlling stake in Hyundai Engineering & Construction was dealt a blow, when a legal advisor said the latest loan-financing document is inadequate.

headline: Moody's Lowers Vietnam's Rating
summary: Moody's downgraded Vietnam's rating  in a further sign of growing doubts over the economy. The agency cited, among other things, debt woes at state-run Vinashin.

headline: Singapore-ASX Deal Clears Hurdle
summary: Australia's competition regulator said it won't oppose Singapore Exchange's $8.4 billion bid for ASX.

headline: Sirens Wail Across South Korea

summary: DBS Group Holdings said it will acquire Royal Bank of Scotland's retail and commercial banking operations in China, the latest move in the Singapore-based bank's aggressive expansion in Asia.

headline: Korea to Raise Energy Self-Sufficiency
summary: As part of its aim to boost energy self-sufficiency next year, South Korea is developing and investing more in overseas energy projects such as the recently announced acquisition of the Canadian assets of Hunt Oil Co.

summary: A devastating blaze raced through a garment factory near Bangladesh's capital Tuesday, killing at least 25 people and injuring more than 100, witnesses and news reports said.

summary: Stocks closed higher as the Federal Reserve stuck to its easy-money policy and economic data showed improvement.

headline: India Favors Keeping Stop-Work Order on Lavasa

summary: France's antitrust watchdog said Google has a dominant position in the French Internet-search advertising market, a decision that could lead to further scrutiny of the web giant's business practices in the country.

headline: Public-Sector Pains Strain Recovery
summary: Public-sector duress threatens to undermine the nation's economic recovery just as the private sector is kicking into gear.

headline: Nokia Delays E7 Smartphone Release

headline: Ratify Start, Put the Inspectors Back
summary: Former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is right to support ratification of the New Start nuclear arms reduction agreement ("New Start: Ratify, With Caveats," op-ed, Dec. 7th). But she could have gone even further.

summary: Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao, on his first trip to India in five years, announced $16 billion in deals between Chinese and Indian companies.

summary: New Pfizer CEO Ian Read shuffled his executive team Tuesday, installing associates he's worked closely with at the pharmaceutical giant while keeping key leaders in their posts.

summary: Oppenheimer must buy back $650,000 in auction-rate securities from a Connecticut couple, a securities arbitration panel has ruled.

summary: The John Dory Oyster Bar, a new hot spot from restaurateur Ken Friedman and chef April Bloomfield, is more bar than restaurant. But that's not stopping the midday crowds.

headline: China Lifts Inflation Target
summary: Beijing said it will raise its inflation target for 2011 to 4% from this year's 3%, acknowledging the consumer prices despite a series of recent tightening measures.

headline: Chicago's Other Sports Curse
summary: The Cubs aren't Chicago's only sports curse. Northwestern's men's basketball team hasn't ever made the NCAA tournament. But that could change this year.

summary: Cliff Lee's signing reminds Manager Terry Collins and his players of the task awaiting them in the NL East.

summary: The IATA expects global airlines' net profit to be $15.1 billion, a margin of just 2.7%.

summary: Hollywood studio Universal Pictures will join cable sibling the Syfy  television network to produce low-cost science fiction, fantasy and horror movies.

summary: Amar'e Stoudemire has scored 30 points in eight straight games, a Knicks franchise record and opposing players say there's a good reason for Mr. Stoudemire's success: He might be the hardest player in the NBA to guard.

summary: The complex supply chain behind the iPhone highlights how conventional trade statistics provide a distorted view of a world where products are designed in one country and assembled in another.

summary: Premier Wen Jiabao's visit to India this week provides New Delhi an opportunity to break the logjam in key policy areas holding it back from tapping China's powerhouse economy.

summary: Moody's warned it may downgrade its ratings on Spanish government debt, in a further sign that Europe's debt worries are spreading closer to the euro-zone core.

summary: Price competition has hurt the specialty-electronics retailer, but its problems run deeper.

summary: Responding to "Scotland's Opportunity," (editorial, Dec. 2).

summary: Cliff Lee has torn through many uniform numbers in the 30s. Now he may face a tough choice with the Phillies. Plus, a marketing firm looks to tap India's basketball potential.

summary: Oil and gas drilling companies are touting what they call new, environmentally friendly formulas to quell fears that they are contaminating water supplies when they tap deep rock formations.

summary: Researching his new book "The Cocktail Collection" with the Luxury Collection Hotels, the mixologist Greg Seider of Summit Bar had no problem winging it.

summary: Inflation may be at bay, but prices are bound to rise again. AllianceBernstein's Real Asset Strategy Fund aims to protect against that.

summary: Republican members of a commission investigating the financial crisis will issue their own report that could undermine the body's formal conclusions.

summary: Prices of municipal bonds fell sharply for the second day, driving yields on long-term bonds to the highest points in more than 18 months.

headline: Mets' Bay Says He's Symptom-Free
summary: Mets leftfielder Jason Bay, whose first season with the team was marred by prolonged slumps and cut short in July by a concussion, said Tuesday that he has been headache-free since September and is ready for the start of spring training.

summary: Atos Origin agreed to buy Siemens's IT Solutions and Services business for $1.14 billion.

headline: What Makes Kids Creative
summary: Americans' scores on a benchmark creativity test have fallen steadily from 1990 to 2008. So parents are stepping into the breach by nurturing their kids' creative skills at home or in their communities.

summary: Fresh off destroying the Washington Capitals, the Rangers get a huge test when they head to Pittsburgh and face the red-hot Penguins.

summary: South Korea, still reeling from the North Korean attack on one of its islands last month, staged what it billed as its biggest civil-defense drills in years, drawing participation from about 20% of the country's 50 million people.

summary: Harley-Davidson introduced the first two motorcycles from its India factory, as the U.S. maker of iconic bikes tries to expand in one of the world's fastest growing two-wheeler markets.

summary: U.S. officials and companies say India's restrictions on imports of solar technology threaten to cut American firms out of a promising market as India embarks on a major rollout of solar power.

headline: The Teachers Union's Status Quo Mediocrity
summary: On the subject of education reform, Dennis van Roekel of the National Education Association writes, "We offer no easy answers, only the promise of hard work" (Letters, Dec 10). As countless data have revealed, hard work and good intentions have led our schools only to mediocrity on the world stage.

headline: Commemorating Operation Exodus
summary: Peter May will this week give $350,000 to the UJA Federation of New York to commemorate the 20th anniversary of Operation Exodus, a seven-year campaign he helped run in New York.

headline: The Frick at a Glowing 75
summary: At a time when museums large and small are in various states of transition, the mansion and collection established by Henry Clay Frick serenely endures.

headline: BAM Gets Cultural Diplomacy Nod
summary: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has been tapped to produce the first official year of DanceMotion USA, a cultural diplomacy project.

headline: Emanuel Defends Himself at Hearing
summary: A year ago, Rahm Emanuel was directing meetings in the White House and pressuring members of Congress to back the president. On Tuesday, in a windowless conference room in Chicago, he tried to keep his run for mayor alive by answering pointed questions about his residency.

headline: Loser Pays, Everyone Wins
summary: Texas pushes the British rule on tort reform.
